org.embulk.spi.json

Class JsonString

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.embulk.spi.json.JsonString
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    JsonValue

    public final class JsonString
extends Object
implements JsonValue
    Represents a string in JSON.

    It represents the string as a String, which is the same as Embulk's STRING column type.

    Since:
    0.10.42
    See Also:
    RFC 8259 - The JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) Data Interchange Format

    • Nested Class Summary

      • Nested classes/interfaces inherited from interface org.embulk.spi.json.JsonValue

        JsonValue.EntityType

    • Method Detail

      • of

        public static JsonString of(String value)
        Returns a JSON string that is represented by the specified String.

        This method does not automatically apply String.intern() for value.

        Parameters:
        value - the string, not null
        Returns:
        a JSON string represented by the specified String
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the string is null
        Since:
        0.10.42

      • withLiteral

        public static JsonString withLiteral(String value,
                                     String literal)
        Returns a JSON string that is represented by the specified String, with the specified JSON literal.

        This method does not automatically apply String.intern() for value.

        The literal is just subsidiary information used when stringifying this JSON string as JSON by toJson(). Note that the literal usually need to be quoted, for example, JsonString.withLiteral("foo\n", "\"foo\\n\"").

        Parameters:
        value - the string, not null
        literal - the JSON literal of the string
        Returns:
        a JSON string represented by the specified String
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if the string is null
        Since:
        0.10.42

      • presumeReferenceSizeInBytes

        public int presumeReferenceSizeInBytes()
        Returns the approximate size of this JSON string in bytes presumed to occupy in Page as a reference.

        This approximate size is used only as a threshold whether PageBuilder is flushed, or not. It is not accurate, it does not need to be accurate, and it is impossible in general to tell an accurate size that a Java object occupies in the Java heap. But, a reasonable approximate would help to keep Page performant in the Java heap.

        It is better to flush more frequently for bigger JSON value objects, less often for smaller JSON value objects, but no infinite accumulation even for empty JSON value objects.

        Specified by:
        presumeReferenceSizeInBytes in interface JsonValue
        Returns:
        the approximate size of this JSON string in bytes presumed to occupy in Page as a reference
        See Also:
        "org.embulk.spi.PageBuilderImpl#addRecord"

      • toJson

        public String toJson()
        Returns the stringified JSON representation of this JSON string.

        If this JSON string is created with a literal by withLiteral(String, String), it returns the literal. Otherwise, it returns an escaped and quoted representation, which is valid as JSON, of this JSON string.

        Specified by:
        toJson in interface JsonValue
        Returns:
        the stringified JSON representation of this JSON string
        Since:
        0.10.42

      • toMsgpack

        @Deprecated
public org.msgpack.value.Value toMsgpack()
        Deprecated. Do not use this method. It is to be removed at some point after Embulk v1.0.0. It is here only to ensure a migration period from MessagePack-based JSON values to new JSON values of JsonValue.
        Returns the corresponding MessagePack's String value of this JSON string.
        Specified by:
        toMsgpack in interface JsonValue
        Returns:
        the corresponding MessagePack's String value of this JSON string
        Since:
        0.10.42
        See Also:
        Draft EEP: JSON Column Type

      • toString

        public String toString()
        Returns the string representation of this JSON string.

        It returns an escaped and quoted representation like "string", which is valid as JSON, of this JSON string.

        It does not consider a literal by withLiteral(String, String) unlike toJson().

        Overrides:
        toString in class Object
        Returns:
        the string representation of this JSON string
        Since:
        0.10.42
